subject: Art
title: Serif vs Sans-Serif
description: The two great typeface families and when to use each.

hook.text: Times New Roman has little feet (serifs) at the ends of its strokes. Helvetica doesn't (sans = without). This seemingly small difference creates entirely different feelings: traditional vs modern, formal vs clean.

buildup.text: Serif typefaces (Times, Garamond, Georgia): small decorative strokes at letter endings. Associated with tradition, authority, books, newspapers. Sans-serif (Helvetica, Arial, Futura): clean, no decorations. Associated with modernity, tech, minimalism.

discovery.text: For long body text in print, serifs traditionally aid readability â€” the feet guide the eye along the baseline. On screens, sans-serif often wins because serifs can blur at small pixel sizes.

twist.text: The serif/sans-serif divide is shrinking. High-resolution screens render serifs beautifully. Many modern serifs look clean and contemporary. The 'serifs = old, sans = modern' stereotype is increasingly outdated.

climax.text: Mix them: serif headings with sans-serif body text (classic contrast) or vice versa. The combination creates visual hierarchy through typographic contrast â€” one of the most powerful design tools.

punchline.text: Serifs add personality. Sans-serifs add clarity. The best designs often use both.

quiz.question: What are serifs?
options: Small decorative strokes at the ends of letter strokes
